{{Infobox musical artist | name = Rick Holmstrom | image = | caption = | image_size = | background = solo_singer | birth_name = | alias = | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1965|5|30|mf=y}}
[[Fairbanks, Alaska]], [[United States]] | death_date = | instrument = [[Guitar]], [[Human voice|vocals]] | genre = [[Electric blues]], [[West Coast blues]], [[rhythm and blues]] | occupation = [[Guitarist]], [[singing|singer]], [[songwriter]], [[record producer]] | years_active = 1985–present | label = [[Black Top Records|Black Top]], Tone-Cool, M.C. | associated_acts = [[William Clarke (musician)|William Clarke]], [[Johnny Dyer]], [[Rod Piazza]], [[Mavis Staples]] | website = [http://rickholmstrom.com/ Official website] }} '''Rick Holmstrom''' (born May 30, 1965) is an [[United States|American]] [[electric blues]] and [[rhythm and blues]] guitarist, singer and songwriter.{{cite web |url={{Allmusic|class=artist|id=p87585|pure_url=yes}} |title=Rick Holmstrom |author=Char Ham |publisher=[[Allmusic]] |accessdate=October 8, 2011}} Holmstrom has previously worked with [[William Clarke (musician)|William Clarke]], [[Johnny Dyer]], and [[Rod Piazza]]. He is currently the bandleader for [[Mavis Staples]].{{cite web|author=Greg Rapaport |url=http://www.instrumentalguitar.info/blog/joelf/2012/06/21/rick-holmstroms-cruel-sunrise-set-worldwide-release-august-28 |title=Rick Holmstrom's "Cruel Sunrise" Set for Worldwide Release August 28 | Guitar Instrumental Music |publisher=Instrumentalguitar.info |date= |accessdate=2012-11-26}} In addition, Holmstrom has played and recorded with [[Jimmy Rogers]], [[Billy Boy Arnold]], [[Jody Williams (blues musician)|Jody Williams]], and [[R. L. Burnside]]. One critic observed of Holmstrom, "he delivers music with technical savvy and traditional stylings, without sacrificing originality and pure adventure".{{cite web|url={{Allmusic|class=album|id=r468256/review|pure_url=yes}} |title=Allmusic ((( ''Gonna Get Wild!'' > Review )))}} ==Life and career== Holmstrom was born in [[Fairbanks, Alaska]], [[United States]], and his father was a [[Disc jockey|DJ]]. After relocating to Southern California, and while attending college in [[Redlands, California]], he joined a local blues group.{{cite web |url=http://www.rickholmstrom.com/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=5&Itemid=29 |title=Biography |author= |date= |work= |publisher=Rickholmstrom.com |accessdate=October 8, 2011}} Holmstrom also went to blues concerts, where he played guitar with [[Smokey Wilson]] and [[Junior Watson]]. He joined [[William Clarke (musician)|William Clarke]]'s backing band, and played both [[lead guitar|lead]] and [[rhythm guitar]] for three years up to 1988. That same year, Holmstrom suffered a significant tragedy in his family, as his father and younger sister were killed in a [[whitewater]] rafting accident in Alaska's [[Wrangell-St. Elias National Park]].{{cite news|title=Film crew's raft trip ends in death; former governor escapes injury in Wrangell St. Elias accident which claims 3|first=David|last=Hulen|newspaper=[[Anchorage Daily News]]|publisher=[[The McClatchy Company]]|location=[[Anchorage]]|date=August 8, 1988|page=A1}}{{cite web|url=http://alaskawhitewater.8m.com/whitewaterdeaths.htm|title=Recent Alaska Whitewater Accidents|first=Ted|last=Coats|date=June 9, 1999|work=TC's Alaska Whitewater Rafting Page|accessdate=April 6, 2013}} Later joining forces with [[Johnny Dyer]], Holmstrom played on his albums, ''Listen Up'' (1994) and ''Shake It!'' (1995). He moved on to join [[Rod Piazza]]'s backing group, the Mighty Flyers and, in 1996, released his first solo album, ''Lookout!'' on [[Black Top Records]]. It was an [[instrumental]] affair, about which one reviewer noted "Holmstrom's inventive ideas are top-notch, making each track stand mightily on its own".{{cite web|url={{Allmusic|class=album|id=r229827/review|pure_url=yes}} |title=Allmusic ((( ''Lookout!'' > Review )))}} However, Holmstrom continued to perform with Piazza, and help him record ''Tough and Tender'' (1997). By 2000, Holmstrom's second solo effort, ''Gonna Get Wild'' was released on Tone-Cool Records, and he stayed long enough with Piazza's backing ensemble to participate on ''Beyond the Source'' (2001). Holmstrom's next release, ''Hydraulic Groove'' (2002) is one of his most daring efforts, where he used [[loop (music)|loops]] and [[Sampling (music)|samples]], and incorporated elements of [[acid jazz]]/[[nu-jazz]], [[funk]] and [[trip-hop]] to his blues, featuring guest performances of [[John Medeski]] and [[DJ Logic]]. ''Hydraulic Groove'' peaked at #9 in the ''[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]'' Top Blues Albums chart.{{cite web|url={{Allmusic|artist/rick-holmstrom-p87585/charts-awards|pure_url=yes}} |title=Allmusic ((( Rick Holmstrom > Charts & Awards > Billboard Albums )))}} In 2005, Holmstrom played at the [[Dark Season Blues]] [[music festival|festival]]. Holmstrom turned to [[record producer|record production]] duties for other musicians before, in 2006, releasing ''Live at the Cafe Boogaloo''. Holmstrom switched [[record label]] to M.C. Records, and in 2007 issued ''Late in the Night''. In 2012, he toured as the guitarist in Mavis Staples' backing band. ==Discography== {| class="wikitable sortable" |- ! Records |}{{cite web|url={{Allmusic|class=artist|id=p87585/discography|pure_url=yes}}|title=Allmusic ((( Rick Holmstrom > Discography > Main Albums )))}} ==See also== *[[List of electric blues musicians]] *[[Black Top Records catalog]] ==References== {{Reflist}} {{Persondata | NAME = Holmstrom, Rick | ALTERNATIVE NAMES = | SHORT DESCRIPTION = [[United States|American]] [[electric blues]] and [[blues rock]] guitarist | DATE OF BIRTH = May 30, 1965 | PLACE OF BIRTH = [[Fairbanks, Alaska]], [[United States]] | DATE OF DEATH = | PLACE OF DEATH = }} {{DEFAULTSORT:Holmstrom, Rick}} [[Category:1965 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:American blues guitarists]] [[Category:American rhythm and blues guitarists]] [[Category:American blues singers]] [[Category:American rhythm and blues singers]] [[Category:American male singers]] [[Category:American record producers]] [[Category:Electric blues musicians]] [[Category:Musicians from Alaska]] [[Category:Songwriters from Alaska]] [[Category:People from Fairbanks, Alaska]]
